title: Project Structure Quiz
description: Test your understanding of feature-first folder organization.

questions.text: Where would you put a reusable 'AppButton' widget that is used across 5 different features?
questions.explanation: Widgets used by multiple features belong in core/widgets/. This keeps reusable code in one place and prevents features from depending on each other. The core/ folder is for shared code.

questions.text: Where would you put the login screen for your authentication feature?
questions.explanation: In feature-first organization, each feature has its own folder. Login is part of the auth feature, so it goes in features/auth/views/. This keeps all authentication-related code together.

questions.text: Your cart feature needs to access the current user's ID. What is the CORRECT way to do this?
options: Copy the user model into features/cart/models/
Use a shared service like services/auth_service.dart
Store user ID in a global variable
questions.explanation: Features should not import from each other directly. Instead, use shared services as intermediaries. This keeps features independent and prevents tight coupling. If auth changes, cart does not break.

questions.text: You created a 'ProductRatingStars' widget used ONLY in the product detail screen. Where should it go?
questions.explanation: If a widget is only used within one feature, it stays in that feature's widgets/ folder. Only put things in core/ if they are used by 2+ features. This prevents core/ from becoming a dumping ground.

questions.text: What is the MAIN advantage of feature-first folder organization?
options: Related code is grouped together, making features easy to find and modify
questions.explanation: Feature-first organization groups all code for a feature (models, views, viewmodels, widgets) in one folder. This makes it easy to find everything related to a feature, work on it without jumping between folders, and even delete an entire feature by removing one folder.
